body:
Hi! @sijie I think #2375 is a bit different from this because is proposed to be 'publisher dependent' being the publisher the one who decides which delay will have each message instead of the consumer, besides that, in the way this feature is implemented I think it would be easy to support #2375 with the current implementation from this pr.

@codelipenghui I also thought in doing this at client side but I see two major downsides about it:

1. There would be a lot of I/O overhead wasted between clients and brokers delivering unnecessary messages.
2. The decision making of expired messages will be made at client side which depends on client clock, being more error prone and difficult to detect and fix by an administrator.

@lovelle 

>The decision making of expired messages will be made at client side which depends on client clock, being more error prone and difficult to detect and fix by an administrator.

If can't depends on client clock, i think publish time now be client-generated

>There would be a lot of I/O overhead wasted between clients and brokers delivering unnecessary messages.

Your worry is very necessary. 

Through our discussion, we can get the following conclusions:

1. Deferred messages consume can't depends on client clock include message publish time.
2. Implement deferred message consume on client-side has lot of downsides(I/O waste, depends on client clock, un-acked messages limitation...)

If on server-side, can delayed dispatch be simpler?

Dispatcher read entries from ledger, i think we just need to check tail message(if generated on server side, publish time is already sorted)
I did tests with `reorderReadSequenceEnabled=true`  and RackawareEnsemblePlacementPolicy and can confirm the WriteSet is not reordered from a preferred rack.

> After making changes to the integration test property

This is a BC break. A configuration which works with 2.1 or 2.2 will not work with this code. 

And even if I were willing to accept a BC break like this, ```endpoint``` and ```bucket``` are far to generic names in the context of the entire ```broker.conf```.
@cbornet sgtm

I can fix the BC issue, but we need to decide on what the future property names will be. My only requests are that we don't use a vendor specific prefix, like "s3Bucket" nor have every permutation of "provider/property", e.g. "GCSBucket", "S3Bucket", "AzureBucket", "rackspace-cloudfiles-us-bucket", "Backblaze-B2-Bucket", etc. As it will make documentation an absolute nightmare.

> what is BC story here? if producer produces a ZSTD compressed message, how do the consumers know about that.
if it requires people to upgrade consumers first and then producers later, we should call out the sequence somewhere (either in javadoc or a separate upgrade doc)

Good point. To use zstd, both producers and consumers will need to be of version >= 2.3. I'll call that out in the Javadoc.

I don't think we should specify in an upgrade doc, since at this point it's not possible to use this compression type. After you upgrade, or in a new application, you can turn that on.

run integration tests
run java8 tests
run java8 tests
run java8 tests

There will likely have to be some vendor specific things, as they don't have 100% compatible features. How about something like:

```
offloader.<vendor>.bucket=
offloader.<vendor>.endpoint=
```

I don't think this adds a much of a documentation burden. We have a core set that work for everyone, and can be documented once. The vendor specific stuff gets documented in their own section. In broker.conf they only need to be added once.
rerun integration tests
That will work....I will make the changes now.  hopefully the JClouds API minimizes the number of vendor unique settings.
run java8 tests

run java8 tests
run integration tests
I didn't mark this ready for review yet.
run java8 tests
#3169 if for this issue
Having an option like this on a Reader would be enough for me to close #2682.

What should be the default value for these options ? Enabled/disabled ?
Should the default policy be rack-aware (current default) or region-aware ?

I expect there will be non-jclouds offloaders too. For example, HDFS.

https://github.com/apache/pulsar/commit/052c3b0dc418d1ec29c3d221023bc7506b672e91 might be helpful as an example of doing weird stuff with the config.
Also, the old config values will still have to work. So you'll need some compatibility translation layer.

> What should be the default value for these options ? Enabled/disabled ?

better to be "disabled"

> Should the default policy be rack-aware (current default) or region-aware ?

I think default policy should be rack-aware since that would be most of the people is using.
GetLastMessageId request is already there. However it is not exposed. It should be very straightforward to expose it. @jiazhai or @legendtkl can help with that.
/cc @legendtkl
We already support submitting .whl files. Does that satisfy this requirement?
Awesome. Yes it does.
I'm assuming that is for **2.3** release though.
run java8 tests
This is actually for 2.2 release.
Interesting. Is the documentation updated around submitting `.whl` as pulsar functions. I can't seem to find it. The release notes for 2.2 does not contain any mentions of this either.
Unfortunately we are a little behind wrt documentation. You can create a wheel file and just submit it using the same --py <wheel file> and things should work fine.
Got it. Thanks for clarifying that.
rerun java8 tests
run integration tests
run integration tests
run java8 tests
run java8 tests
run java8 tests

>  doesn't actually do anything to prevent the broker from serving traffic before it's ready, it just doesn't advertize it. 

That is correct. Ideally the 6650 port should only be opened when all the components of the service are ready to accept requests. 

> Not sure if this is problematic. 

The fix for #2935 was to cover for the problem of using schema service before it was actually initialized. I think this might actually still be a problem when the lookup is bypassed since the broker service get started before the schema registry service.
There was a conversation about whether to expose it when implementing Reader#hasMessageAvailable().
Ok, lets create an issue for this at least. I'll close this one.

@alapha23 Sorry missed this issue before.

The problem is that `go get` fetches the code from master which has moved on since the 2.2.0 release.

The Pulsar Go code needs to match the same version of `apache-pulsar-client` RPM. 

You can use `dep ensure -add github.com/apache/pulsar/pulsar-client-go/pulsar@v2.2.0` to force a release version on the Go code.
run cpp tests
run java8 tests
rerun java8 tests
rerun java8 tests
PR looks good just some minor comments
Thanks @jerrypeng. Will be addressing them ;)
run integration tests
run java8 tests

@codelipenghui 

> If can't depends on client clock, i think publish time now be client-generated

Yes, as far as I understand publish time is set [here](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/blob/master/pulsar-client/src/main/java/org/apache/pulsar/client/impl/ProducerImpl.java#L348) this should be set by broker instead of client, do you see any problem in doing so?

Just to clarify this one step further, I can see two main features with the `delayed message` topic.

1. Consumer dependent delay (this pr) would be used just to having some delay on _every_ message of the consumer, maybe for short period of times, in the range or less than minutes. And the obvious advantage is that the producer does not need to be aware of such delay.

2. Publisher dependent delay (#2375 and [here](https://github.com/apache/pulsar/wiki/PIP-26%3A-Delayed-Message-Delivery)) I think this feature is more advance and complex and the proposed way is a really good path, since the time of delay for deliver such messages could be far in time and totally different from each other, therefore, messages need to be structured in consideration with this factor.

I think both approaches would be great to have on pulsar since they are used for different purposes.

So, on 2nd approach we could do what you propose if I'm not wrong.
run cpp tests
run integration tests
rerun integration tests
rerun java8 tests

Thank you for the reply. 
I fixed the issue by a checkout to the correct branch. Thank you for the feedback.

@erenavsarogullari Thanks for the great work. overall lgtm.

@JevonQ I am wondering why don't you use pulsar python client?
@ewh you can find the current list of supported platforms here: https://pypi.org/project/pulsar-client/2.2.0/#files

> I don't think we should specify in an upgrade doc, since at this point it's not possible to use this compression type. After you upgrade, or in a new application, you can turn that on.

I think we need to document the process if people want to enable this compression type. especially the consumers have to upgrade before producers. I think we should call this out, like what we did for the changes in pulsar 2.0. https://pulsar.apache.org/docs/en/pulsar-2.0/
rerun java8 tests
This PR is ready for review

The producer and consumer are using Java client, we need to guarantee it will be well tested. Unfortunately, our test cases has to be written in Python, so I have to use Jpype to call Java client in the test cases.

@sijie  Thanks for the review.
Comments have been addressed. PR is ready for re-review.
rerun java8 tests
